p: In angiosperms, only the maize gene TPS1 produces ( E)-β-farnesene (26%), ( E)-nerolidol (29%), and ( E, E)-farnesol (45%) as the only three products in vitro [ 59]. Phylogenetically, SaTPS3 is paraphyletic group with other TPSs of Santalum spp. in the TPS-b group (Fig. 3). The function of SaTPS3 is similar to TPS1 in maize where it catalyzes the formation of three major compounds, i.e. ( E)-β-farnesene (20.7%), ( E)-nerolidol (29.8%) and ( E,E)-farnesol (21.3%). However, SaTPS3 additionally synthesized γ-bisabolene, cedrene and two unknown sesquiterpene compounds in relative amounts that exceeded 28%, suggesting that SaTPS3 is not a highly conserved TPS in angiosperms. Diversity of function may be an evolution of adaptive selection in monocotyledons and dicotyledons.
